displayTitle: Why do we need the GDPR?
title: Why do we need the GDPR?

displayTitle: More control over data about you
title: More control over data about you

body: Under what circumstances is it acceptable to transfer an individual’s personal data to another country outside of the EU?
title: International transfers

_items.text: In order to help process the data, eg on cloud servers
When it is absolutely necessary to fulfil the lawful basis
When the individual has explicitly consented for their data to be transferred to this country
When it is in the general interest of the individual

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The GDPR makes it much easier to transfer data within the EU.

Transfers outside of the EU may be made:

  • to locations the European Commission has decided an adequate level of protection is afforded
  • to organisations where appropriate protection is afforded through contractual clauses
  • with the individual's informed consent
  • where it is absolutely necessary for the fulfilment of the lawful basis

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The GDPR makes it much easier to transfer data within the EU.

Transfers outside of the EU may be made:

  • to locations the European Commission has decided an adequate level of protection is afforded
  • to organisations where appropriate protection is afforded through contractual clauses
  • with the individual's informed consent
  • where it is absolutely necessary for the fulfilment of the lawful basis

body: What is wrong with the privacy notice shown here?
title: Privacy notices

_items.text: Not clear who personal information will be shared with
Marketing should be opt-in, not out
A link to this training should be included

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

This is an example of a particularly bad privacy notice. There is a mix of confusing language, incorrect terminology and misleading information. Additionally the signature box is in the incorrect place. On top of everything outlined here, under the GDPR you must allow an electronic request for access to the data, and fulfil this with an electronic copy of the data, unless otherwise requested.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

This is an example of a particularly bad privacy notice. There is a mix of confusing language, incorrect terminology and misleading information. Additionally the signature box is in the incorrect place. On top of everything outlined here, under the GDPR you must allow an electronic request for access to the data, and fulfil this with an electronic copy of the data, unless otherwise requested.

body: What is wrong with the privacy notice shown here?
title: Privacy notices

_items.text: Not clear what a subject access request is
There cannot be a charge for the right to access
The signature box comes before the terms are complete

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

This is an example of a particularly bad privacy notice. There is a mix of confusing language, incorrect terminology and misleading information. Additionally the signature box is in the incorrect place. On top of everything outlined here, under the GDPR you must allow an electronic request for access to the data, and fulfil this with an electronic copy of the data, unless otherwise requested.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

This is an example of a particularly bad privacy notice. There is a mix of confusing language, incorrect terminology and misleading information. Additionally the signature box is in the incorrect place. On top of everything outlined here, under the GDPR you must allow an electronic request for access to the data, and fulfil this with an electronic copy of the data, unless otherwise requested.

body: The GDPR introduces the right to data portability which gives individuals the right to:
title: Individual rights

_items.text: Request a machine-readable copy of data held about them that they have provided
Transfer data they have provided freely to another organisation
Use their mobile data plan anywhere in the world
Request their data be made available for sale

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The GDPR introduces a new data portability right – the right for an individual to receive personal data they have provided to the controller or that has been gathered automatically by the controller. This must be provided in a commonly used and machine readable format. Additionally the individual has the right to request that the data is transmitted directly to another controller.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The GDPR introduces a new data portability right - the right for an individual to receive personal data they have provided to the controller or that has been gathered automatically by the controller. This must be provided in a commonly used and machine readable format. Additionally the individual has the right to request that the data is transmitted directly to another controller.

body: If the service you are providing to an individual could be provided without collecting personal data then how does the lawful basis apply?
displayTitle: Establishing lawful basis for processing personal data
title: Establishing lawful basis for processing personal data

_items.text: You can use the lawful basis to collection personal data anyway
It no longer applies and thus your collection and processing of personal data is unlawful (with the exception of consent)
You can collect the data just in case it becomes useful for any other lawful service

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The GDPR requires everyone to process personal data lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner.

There are six lawful bases outlined in the GDPR and at least one must apply; without a lawful basis, it is illegal to collect and process the personal data. 

Additionally, with the exception of consent, if you could reasonably perform your tasks without collecting the personal data then the lawful basis does not apply.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The GDPR requires everyone to process personal data lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner.

There are six lawful bases outlined in the GDPR and at least one must apply; without a lawful basis, it is illegal to collect and process the personal data. 

Additionally, with the exception of consent, if you could reasonably perform your tasks without collecting the personal data then the lawful basis does not apply.

body: Which of the following services (that processes personal data) does the FCO have a legal obligation to provide?
displayTitle: Establishing lawful basis for processing personal data
title: Establishing lawful basis for processing personal data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The FCO is legally obliged to respond to requests for information. We have names and contact details of requesters to enable us to communicate with them. We are also required to ask for certain further personal details to verify the identities of those making Subject Access Requests.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The FCO is legally obliged to respond to requests for information. We have names and contact details of requesters to enable us to communicate with them. We are also required to ask for certain further personal details to verify the identities of those making Subject Access Requests.

body: What do ‘special categories of personal data’ refer to?
title: Special categories of personal data

_items.text: Data that could create more significant risks to a person's fundamental rights and freedoms
User account passwords and other access keys

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

‘Special categories of personal data’ (previously referred to as sensitive personal data) merit higher protection as the context of their processing could create significant risks to fundamental rights and freedoms.

These categories include:

  • Racial or ethnic origin
  • Political opinions
  • Religious or philosophical beliefs
  • Trade union membership
  • Genetic and biometric data (new in the GDPR)
  • Physical or mental health or conditions
  • Sex life or sexual orientation

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

‘Special categories of personal data’ (previously referred to as sensitive personal data) merit higher protection as the context of their processing could create significant risks to fundamental rights and freedoms.

These categories include:

  • Racial or ethnic origin
  • Political opinions
  • Religious or philosophical beliefs
  • Trade union membership
  • Genetic and biometric data (new in the GDPR)
  • Physical or mental health or conditions
  • Sex life or sexual orientation

_bands.feedback: Could do better! You achieved a score of {{score}}/10.  The lessons would be really valuable to you. Perhaps think about going through the practical lessons before retaking the quiz!

You got half or more right, achieving a score of {{score}}/10.  You have some good knowledge but need to brush up in a few areas. Take a look back at the practical lessons to help fill the gaps in your knowledge.

_items.text: The GDPR is a new regulation that is designed to provide a greater level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals through accountability and transparency
A optional European Directive that organisations are choosing to implement
A means to decrease the amount of spam emails and calls people receive

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The GDPR is a new regulation that is designed to provide a greater level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals through accountability and transparency.

Anyone who deals with personal data must be aware of what they can and cannot do with this data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The GDPR is a new regulation that is designed to provide a greater level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals through accountability and transparency.

Anyone who deals with personal data must be aware of what they can and cannot do with this data.

body: Can you remember a time when you were a child and you accidentally broke something. Did you own up? Or was the fear or being told off too great?
displayTitle: What to do if the GDPR has been breached
title: What to do if the GDPR has been breached

body:
At the Open Data Institute we do not confirm to a 'whistle blowing approach'. We are open by nature. If you think you have breached the GDPR please act quickly and inform your line manager. The quicker you act, the easier we can work together to provide solutions.

The GDPR introduces a duty on all organisations to report any serious data breach to the relevant supervisory authority. A personal data breach means a breach of security leading to the unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to, personal data. This includes both accidental and deliberate breaches.

As we saw earlier, significant penalties can be imposed on any organisation who breaches the GDPR.
title: What to do if the GDPR has been breached

body: Think back to 1998. A time when we waited several minutes to dial up to broadband and the most we could do on our mobile phones was make calls or send pixilated text messages. Now, some 20 years later and our Smart Phones connect to everything, to everyone, at every moment.
title: Why now?

_items.title: Aims of the GDPR
_items.body: The last time our data protection laws were revised were in 1998. To ensure our privacy is protected and to maintain the power balance between us as individuals and corporations, we need an update. The GDPR, aims to 'harmonise' data privacy laws within the EU and introduce a more robust compliancy framework which focuses on the increased protection of fundamental rights and freedom of individuals. Being open about how personal data is used, and how privacy is protected can help to build trust in organisations which collect and use personal data.

_items.title: Where does it apply?
_items.body:
The GDPR applies to the processing of all personal data by organisations in the European Union (EU), regardless of whether the processing takes place in the EU or not.

Processing personal data covers the following, irrespective of how the data is collected:
collection, recording, organisation, structuring, storage, adaptation or alteration, retrieval, consultation, use, disclosure by transmission, dissemination or otherwise making available, alignment or combination, restriction, erasure or destruction.

body: Remember, just as change is a process rather than event, compliance is an ongoing journey. At the ODI we lead by example and combine compliance with great innovation. We are all a part of helping the business to keep iterating and improving.
title: Component title

body:
Modification to or unauthorised destruction of data or documents containing personal data

Always check which files can or cannot be altered or deleted.

Loss or theft of staff equipment or devices

Keep tabs on any devices you are responsible for (e.g. mobile phone, laptop, USB stick, CD, tablet, voice recorder etc.) both at work and in public spaces.

Unauthorised use

Be aware of who has access to company data or IT systems.

Incorrect or unauthorised sharing

Ensure you know how and who data can be shared with.

Human error

Be sure to track any client-facing interfaces i.e. social media. Mistakes can happen.
title: Examples of a data breach

body:
As we have seen, the GDPR will strengthen existing individual rights over personal data as well as introducing new ones. Of these, data portability is something we talk widely about here at the ODI and there is much discussion over its potential in driving innovation and creating new products and services.

The re-use of data across other services may play a significant role in addressing the lack of competition in markets for example, where users could be given wider choice of switching between providers of the same. 

One example of sites which facilitate data of this type is Money Supermarket. Can you think of any other examples?

Want to know more about data portability? Read the blog written by Gillian and Jack here.
displayTitle: How increased rights can support innovation
title: How increased rights can support innovation

_items.title: Special categories of personal data
_items.body:
Previously referred to as sensitive data, special categories of personal data require higher a higher level of protection as the context of their processing could create serious risks to the fundamental rights and freedoms of a person. These include:

  • racial or ethnic origin
  • political opinions
  • religious or philosophical beliefs
  • trade union membership
  • genetic and biometric data (new in the GDPR)
  • physical or mental health or conditions
  • sex life or sexual orientation

_items.title: Criminal convictions data
_items.body:
Data relating to criminal convictions and offences, or related security measures may only be carried when:

  • it is under the control of an official authority.
  • the processing is authorised by Union or Member State law providing for appropriate safeguards for people's rights and freedoms.

_items.title: Data about children
_items.body: Data about children must be treated carefully as they may be less aware of the risks involved. When consent is required for the use of data about someone under 16 years old, that consent must be given by a holder of parental responsibility for that child

_graphic.attribution: Icons made by Freepik from www.flaticon.com is licensed by CC 3.0

body: Natalia is a Delivery Manager at the ODI. When Natalia starts a new project, she follows the requirements of the Privacy by Design model.
title: Component title

body: As well as having access to a privacy notice, there are 8 additional rights which a person can choose to exercise at their will. As you read through each one, think about the role the ODI plays in dealing with these questions.
title: Know your rights!
instruction: Click on a box to find out more

_items.title: A right to access
_items.body:
Are you processing my data?

Where is my data being processed?

And for what purpose?

Organisations have one month from the request to provide a copy of the personal data in an electronic format where possible.

_items.title: A right to rectification
_items.body:
My data is wrong. Can you correct it?

Personal data can be corrected if inaccurate or incomplete. This also applies to any copies shared with others.

_items.title: A right to be forgotten
_items.body:
Can you erase the personal data about me?

Going forward, can you stop sharing my data?

Can you stop third parties processing my data?

When an individual withdraws consent, data must be erased.

Data must also be erased if it is no longer relevant to the original purpose for processing or no lawful basis exists for the data to be held and processed.

_items.title: A right to restrict processing
_items.body: INFO?

_items.title: A right to data portability
_items.body:
Can I see a copy of the personal data I have given you, or that you have automatically gathered from me?

Can you transmit my data directly to another organisation? 

An organisation must provide this in a commonly-used, machine readable format.

_items.title: A right to withdraw consent (where applicable)
_items.body:
Can I withdraw my consent?

If the lawful basis for processing data is based on consent the individual has the right to withdraw at any time. 

The process should be as simple as opting to consent in the first place.

_items.title: A right to object
_items.body:
Can you stop processing data about me?

The right only applies in certain circumstances.

If one of the following is met, the right can be exercised:

  • When data is used for direct marketing 
  • When data is used for research or statistical purposes (unless necessary for public interest i.e. health research)
  • When the data is processed on public or legitimate interests.

_items.title: A right to not be subject solely to automated decision making
_items.body:
Are decisions being made about my data via automated processing?

Automated processing can be carried out if the decision is:

  • Necessary for the entry into/performance of a contract
  • Authorised in law
  • Based on the individual's explicit consent

Individuals must be informed as well as be permitted to request human intervention or challenge a decision.

_items.title: Contract
_items.body:
Is the processing necessary for a contract the organisation has with an individual? 

Has an individual asked you to take specific steps before entering into a contract?

_items.title: Legal obligation
_items.body: Is the processing necessary for you to comply with legal obligation?

_items.title: Vital interests
_items.body: Is the processing necessary to protect an individual's life?

_items.title: Public tasks
_items.body:
Is the processing necessary for you to perform a task in the public interest? 

Is it necessary for you to perform your official functions (providing it has a clear lawful basis)?

_items.title: Legitimate interests
_items.body:
Is the processing necessary for your legitimate interests?

Is it necessary for the legitimate interests of a third party? 

*Unless there is a good reason to protect the individual's personal data, overriding those interests.

_items.title: Consent
_items.body: Has the individual given clear consent for your to process their personal data for a specific purpose?

body: The GDPR requires everyone to process personal data lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner. There are six lawful bases outlined in the GDPR. At least one must apply. Without a lawful basis, it is illegal to collect and process personal data.
displayTitle: A lawful basis for processing data
title: A lawful basis for processing data

body:
Today there are so many ways that we are able to identify someone. How many can you think of?

Under the GDPR, personal data refers to any data relating to an identifiable person. This means anything which can result in the direct or indirect identification of an individual. Remember, people can also be identified by physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social factors.

In isolation, the examples listed on the left may not necessarily make a person identifiable - take the common name, John Smith. We could be talking about a number of different men. But combine this with other data like John's address and his date of birth and suddenly we are talking about John Smith, 30 years old from Cherry Tree Lane, Islington, London.
title: Component title

body:
On the 25th May 2018 the General Data Protection Regulation will come into effect, as part of modernising data protection regulations across the European Union. It will be the biggest shake up to global privacy laws for more than 20 years and here at the ODI we are harnessing this change in the law to enable great innovation. 

  • What exactly is the GDPR?
  • How does it affect us here at the Open Data Institute? 
  • How does it affect our rights as individuals?
  • How can we follow codes of best practice to ensure we keep our data safe?
title: The General Data Protection Regulation

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

body:
The ODI’s privacy and openness principles set targets for organisations aspiring to build trust in how they manage personal data. We take pride in the work we're doing with other organisations in light of the GDPR.

Click here to find out what we've been doing with APIs in the telecoms industry
title: Component title

body:
With all the new rules and regulations, how have you been allowed to use staff photos in this module?

You are probably wondering how we've been allowed to use Natalia's image here. Photographs are still personal data and as such are protected under the 6 lawful basis for processing data.  Under the GDPR you will need to obtain written consent from any subject(s) appearing in an image.
title: Photos

body:
All of our staff here at the Open Data Institute must globally apply the GDPR when processing any type of personal data. This could be HR and employee records, member information and customer lists. Even if you are in a department or role that does not deal with large quantities of personal data, it is likely that at some point you will find yourself handling it.

Can you recall the last time you handled personal data? Maybe you compiled a guest list, sent out information for an event, or sent a group email to your customers.
title: Who and what is affected?

body:
When was the last time you bought something online? Before you submitted your personal details did you check or uncheck the privacy boxes? 

Privacy notices are one of the most visible aspects that demonstrate compliance with the GDPR. Within a notice individuals must be clearly informed about:

  • What data is collected
  • What data is being used for and how we can exercise our rights over the data.

This information must be presented to the individual as near to the point of data collection as possible. 

In addition to fines being imposed for non-compliance, they can also be imposed where a privacy notice is deemed unclear or misleading. And with maximum fines of £17 million, this is no light issue.
title: Privacy

body:
Being open about how personal data is used, and how privacy is protected, helps to build trust in organisations collecting and using personal data. Greater trust means less friction when developing new ideas and services, and greater use of existing ones. It facilitates more connections and network effects. It helps consumers feel empowered, and leads to more informed choices about services that involve collection of personal data. Openness makes things better.

The principles encourage organisations to commit to being ‘open’ in a number of ways. ‘Open’ means both sharing information (publicly online and directly to people), and being open to feedback from people about how things could be improved.
title: The GDPR and our principals

body: If you think you have identified a potential personal data breach, what should you do?
title: Data breaches

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

If you think you have identified a potential personal data breach you should notify the Data Protection Officer who will then decide on the next course of action. 

Breach notification is mandatory where a data breach is likely to result in a risk for the rights and freedoms of individuals. The FCO must report any such data breaches and those affected, to the ICO within 72 hours of becoming aware of them. We must also keep a record of any personal data breaches, regardless of whether we are required to notify.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

If you think you have identified a potential personal data breach you should notify the Data Protection Officer who will then decide on the next course of action. 

Breach notification is mandatory where a data breach is likely to result in a risk for the rights and freedoms of individuals. The FCO must report any such data breaches and those affected, to the ICO within 72 hours of becoming aware of them. We must also keep a record of any personal data breaches, regardless of whether we are required to notify.

body: True or False: An individual’s personal data can only be transferred to countries within the EU?
title: International transfers

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The GDPR makes it much easier to transfer data within the EU.

Transfers outside of the EU may be made:

  • to locations the European Commission has decided an adequate level of protection is afforded
  • to organisations where appropriate protection is afforded through contractual clauses
  • with the individual's informed consent
  • where it is absolutely necessary for the fulfilment of the lawful basis

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The GDPR makes it much easier to transfer data within the EU.

Transfers outside of the EU may be made:

  • to locations the European Commission has decided an adequate level of protection is afforded
  • to organisations where appropriate protection is afforded through contractual clauses
  • with the individual's informed consent
  • where it is absolutely necessary for the fulfilment of the lawful basis

body: Which of the following rights are introduced or enhanced for individuals in the GDPR?
title: Individual rights

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

One of main changes introduced by the GDPR is the addition and enhancement of a number of individual rights including the right to access, right to erasure and right to portability.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

One of main changes to GDPR Is the addition and enhancement of a number of individuals rights including the right to access, right to erasure and right to portability.

body: Which countries can an individual’s personal data be transferred to (without needing to gain consent and it is not necessary in order to fulfil the legal basis)?
title: International transfers

_items.text: Any third country approved by the European Commission that offers an adequate level of data protection

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The GDPR makes it much easier to transfer data within the EU.

Transfers outside of the EU may be made:

  • to locations the European Commission has decided an adequate level of protection is afforded
  • to organisations where appropriate protection is afforded through contractual clauses
  • with the individual's informed consent
  • where it is absolutely necessary for the fulfilment of the lawful basis

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The GDPR makes it much easier to transfer data within the EU.

Transfers outside of the EU may be made:

  • to locations the European Commission has decided an adequate level of protection is afforded
  • to organisations where appropriate protection is afforded through contractual clauses
  • with the individual's informed consent
  • where it is absolutely necessary for the fulfilment of the lawful basis

body: Under the GDPR, in certain circumstances, individuals have the right to request a copy of data they have provided. How much can be changed for this service?
title: Individual rights

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The GDPR give rights of access to individuals to find out from the data controller whether or not personal data concerning them is being processed, and if it is, to access it as well as information about how the data is being collected, used and shared. 

While rights to access are present under the Data Protection Act (DPA), the GDPR specifies that the right to request and access personal data should be free of charge.

The GDPR also states that if the individual makes the request electronically, the information should be provided electronically, unless otherwise requested.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The GDPR give rights of access to individuals to find out from the data controller whether or not personal data concerning them is being processed, and if it is, to access it as well as information about how the data is being collected, used and shared. 

While rights to access are present under the Data Protection Act (DPA), the GDPR specifies that the right to request and access personal data should be free of charge.

The GDPR also states that if the individual makes the request electronically, the information should be provided electronically, unless otherwise requested.

body: Under the GDPR, in certain circumstances, individuals have the right to request a copy of data they have provided. How should this be provided?
title: Individual rights

_items.text: In a commonly used machine readable format

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The GDPR give rights of access to individuals to find out from the data controller whether or not personal data concerning them is being processed, and if it is, to access it as well as information about how the data is being collected, used and shared. 

While rights to access are present under the Data Protection Act (DPA), the GDPR specifies that the right to request and access personal data should be free of charge.

The GDPR also states that if the individual makes the request electronically, the information should be provided electronically, unless otherwise requested.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The GDPR give rights of access to individuals to find out from the data controller whether or not personal data concerning them is being processed, and if it is, to access it as well as information about how the data is being collected, used and shared. 

While rights to access are present under the Data Protection Act (DPA), the GDPR specifies that the right to request and access personal data should be free of charge.

The GDPR also states that if the individual makes the request electronically, the information should be provided electronically, unless otherwise requested.

body: The GDPR introduces the right to be forgotten which gives individuals the right to:
title: Individual rights

_items.text: Request that the data controller erase their personal data
Be removed from official and legal documents, such as police records
Be edited out of a TV show where previously consent was given

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The right to be forgotten (or the right to data erasure) entitles the data subject (where conditions permit) to direct the data controller to erase personal data concerning him or her, cease further sharing of the data, and potentially have third parties halt processing of the data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The right to be forgotten (or the right to data erasure) entitles the data subject (where conditions permit) to direct the data controller to erase personal data concerning him or her, cease further sharing of the data, and potentially have third parties halt processing of the data.

body: Within what time period of becoming aware of a serious data breach should this be reported to the supervisory authority?
title: Data breaches

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Breach notification is mandatory where a data breach is likely to result in a risk for the rights and freedoms of individuals. You must do this within 72 hours of becoming aware of the breach. You must also inform those affected individuals without undue delay.

You must also keep a record of any personal data breaches, regardless of whether you are required to notify.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Breach notification is mandatory where a data breach is likely to result in a risk for the rights and freedoms of individuals. You must do this within 72 hours of becoming aware of the breach. You must also inform those affected individuals without undue delay.

You must also keep a record of any personal data breaches, regardless of whether you are required to notify.

body: What is a Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA)?
title: GDPR by default

_items.text: A compulsory yearly audit of your organisation’s data protection policies
A tool that you can use to identify and reduce the privacy risks of your projects.
A retrospective at the end of a project to analyse whether data protection was adequate

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

A Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) is a tool that you can use to identify and reduce the privacy risks of your projects.

A DPIA helps you to:

  • describe the nature, scope, context and purposes of the processing
  • assess necessity, proportionality and compliance measures
  • identify and assess risks to individuals
  • identify any additional measures to mitigate those risks

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

A Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) is a tool that you can use to identify and reduce the privacy risks of your projects.

A DPIA helps you to:

  • describe the nature, scope, context and purposes of the processing
  • assess necessity, proportionality and compliance measures
  • identify and assess risks to individuals
  • identify any additional measures to mitigate those risks

body: Which of the following are legal requirements under the GDPR?
title: GDPR by default

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

‘Privacy by design’ is a legal requirement. It requires organisations to consider individuals’ privacy from the start of the design of any system or service rather than being bolted on at the end. 

The GDPR also introduces a duty on all organisations to report any serious data breach to the relevant supervisory authority.

The GDPR requires the appointment a data protection officer (DPO) if you are a public authority, or if you carry out certain types of processing activities involving large scales of personal data or special categories of personal data.

The GDPR requires personal data to be processed in a manner that ensures its security. It requires that appropriate technical or organisational measures are used.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

‘Privacy by design’ is a legal requirement. It requires organisations to consider individuals’ privacy from the start of the design of any system or service rather than being bolted on at the end. 

The GDPR also introduces a duty on all organisations to report any serious data breach to the relevant supervisory authority.

The GDPR requires the appointment a data protection officer (DPO) if you are a public authority, or if you carry out certain types of processing activities involving large scales of personal data or special categories of personal data.

The GDPR requires personal data to be processed in a manner that ensures its security. It requires that appropriate technical or organisational measures are used.

body: Which individuals does the GDPR apply to?
displayTitle: Who does the GDPR apply to and where?
title: Who does the GDPR apply to and where?

_items.text: All individuals interacting with an organisation operating in the EU, regardless of nationality
All EU citizens interacting with any company worldwide

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The GDPR will apply to the processing of all personal data by organisations in the EU, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the EU or not.

The GDPR will also apply to the processing of personal data in the EU by an organisation not established in the EU, where the activities relate to either:

  1. Offering goods or services within EU (irrespective of whether payment is required)
  2. Monitoring of individuals behaviour as far as their behaviour takes place within the EU

This means that even if a company has no physical base in the EU, the GDPR may still apply if goods and services are offered to those located within the EU.

On this basis you do not need to be an EU citizen for the GDPR to apply. Anyone located in the EU interacting with services offered in the EU is in scope of the GDPR.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The GDPR will apply to the processing of all personal data by organisations in the EU, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the EU or not.

The GDPR will also apply to the processing of personal data in the EU by an organisation not established in the EU, where the activities relate to either:

  1. Offering goods or services within EU (irrespective of whether payment is required)
  2. Monitoring of individuals behaviour as far as their behaviour takes place within the EU

This means that even if a company has no physical base in the EU, the GDPR may still apply if goods and services are offered to those located within the EU.

On this basis you do not need to be an EU citizen for the GDPR to apply. Anyone located in the EU interacting with services offered in the EU is in scope of the GDPR.

body: Which of the following are examples of special categories of personal data?
title: Special categories of personal data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

‘Special categories of personal data’ (previously referred to as sensitive personal data) merit higher protection as the context of their processing could create significant risks to fundamental rights and freedoms.

These categories include:

  • Racial or ethnic origin
  • Political opinions
  • Religious or philosophical beliefs
  • Trade union membership
  • Genetic and biometric data (new in GDPR)
  • Physical or mental health or conditions
  • Sex life or sexual orientation

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

‘Special categories of personal data’ (previously referred to as sensitive personal data) merit higher protection as the context of their processing could create significant risks to fundamental rights and freedoms.

These categories include:

  • Racial or ethnic origin
  • Political opinions
  • Religious or philosophical beliefs
  • Trade union membership
  • Genetic and biometric data (new in GDPR)
  • Physical or mental health or conditions
  • Sex life or sexual orientation

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

body: Is a picture of a group of people a piece of personal data?
title: What is personal data?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

 

Under the GDPR ’personal data; means any information relating to an identified or identifiable person. 

This covers any piece of information that can result in the identification of a person, either directly or indirectly.

Names are not needed to identify someone; you probably don't know the names of all your neighbours but you can identify them in a picture. A digital picture may also offer other information, such as location and timestamp.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

 

Under the GDPR ’personal data; means any information relating to an identified or identifiable person. 

This covers any piece of information that can result in the identification of a person, either directly or indirectly.

Names are not needed to identify someone; you probably don't know the names of all your neighbours but you can identify them in a picture. A digital picture may also offer other information, such as location and timestamp.

body: Which are the following are examples of personal data covered by the GDPR?
title: What is personal data?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Under the GDPR, 'personal data' means any information relating to an identified or identifiable person.

This covers any piece of information that can result in the identification of a person, either directly or indirectly.

This could be via any identifier, such as a name, email, address, phone number, an identification number, an online identifier (including IP address) or factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that person.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Under the GDPR, 'personal data' means any information relating to an identified or identifiable person.

This covers any piece of information that can result in the identification of a person, either directly or indirectly.

This could be via any identifier, such as a name, email, address, phone number, an identification number, an online identifier (including IP address) or factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that person.

body: What is the definition of personal data in the GDPR?
title: What is personal data?

_items.text: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable person
Any data owned by an individual
Sensitive data, such as health records or salary

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

This covers any piece of information that can result in the identification of a person, either directly or indirectly.

This could be via any identifier, such as a name, email, address, phone number, an identification number, an online identifier (including IP address) or factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that person.

_incorrect.final:

body:
Under the GDPR, public authorities are required to appoint a Data Protection Officer or DPO. Our Data Protection Officer is Leigh Dodds.

Leigh and monitors internal compliance and acts as a contact point both internally and externally. Leigh can offer you:

  • advice on data protection obligations
  • advice regarding Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs)

You can also seek advice from the rest of the policy team who will be able to share their knowledge.

click here for link
title: Component title

body:
Test your knowledge of the GDPR with the 10 questions below. 

Warning: Do not leave your assessment session as you will not be able to resume your assessment.
displayTitle: Test your knowledge of the GDPR
title: Test your knowledge of the GDPR

displayTitle: Which of the following are key objectives of the GDPR?
title: Which of the following are key objectives of the GDPR?

_items.text: Make it simpler to work with personal data throughout the EU
Increase penalties to raise money for the EU
Make it harder for businesses to work with personal data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The GDPR provides standardisation of data protection laws across all European member states, making it easier for organisations to provide services to people across the EU. It also provides a clearer set of rights to individuals.

While penalties do increase, income generation is not a key objective of the GDPR.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The GDPR provides standardisation of data protection laws across all European member states, making it easier for organisations to provide services to people across the EU. It also provides a clearer set of rights to individuals.

While penalties do increase, income generation is not a key objective of the GDPR.

body: What is the role of the Data Protection Officer (DPO)?
title: GDPR-specific roles

_items.text: DPOs monitor compliance, inform and advise on data protection obligations
DPOs are responsible for spotting data breaches
DPOs complete Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs) for you

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

DPOs monitor internal compliance, inform and advise on data protection obligations, provide advice regarding Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs) and act as a contact point for the organisation both internally and externally.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

DPOs monitor internal compliance, inform and advise on data protection obligations, provide advice regarding Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs) and act as a contact point for the organisation both internally and externally.

body: Which lawful basis is most likely to cover services offered by the FCO?
displayTitle: Establishing lawful basis for processing personal data
title: Establishing lawful basis for processing personal data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Most of what that FCO does falls under this legal basis. But we should be careful not to make it our default without considering the other bases first and whether additional ones also apply.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Most of what that FCO does falls under this legal basis. But we should be careful not to make it our default without considering the other bases first and whether additional ones also apply.

body:
'Privacy by design' is a legal requirement. It requires organisations to consider people’s privacy from the start of the design of any system or service and not just bolt it on at the end.

Where data processing is likely to result in a high risk to individuals, a Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) is required under the GDPR. 

A DPIA helps you to:

  • describe the nature, scope, context and purposes of the processing
  • assess necessity, proportionality and compliance measures
  • identify and assess risks to individuals
  • identify any additional measures to mitigate those risks

It's important that we publish out DPIAs as openly as possible.
title: DPIA

displayTitle: What is the relationship between the GDPR and existing European Union data protection regulations?
title: What is the relationship between the GDPR and existing European Union data protection regulations?

_items.text: The GDPR replaces current European Union regulations
The GDPR is an advisory on how to update regulations
The GDPR is a supplementary regulation

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The GDPR replaces current European Union data protection regulations and is designed to provide a greater level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals through accountability and transparency.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The GDPR replaces current European Union data protection regulations and is designed to provide a greater level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals through accountability and transparency.

_items.text: The GDPR provides standardisation of data protection laws across all European member states, making it easier for organisations to provide services to people in the EU
A optional European Directive that organisations are choosing to implement
A means to decrease the amount of spam emails and calls people receive

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The GDPR provides standardisation of data protection laws across all European member states, making it easier for organisations to provide services to people in the EU.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The GDPR provides standardisation of data protection laws across all European member states, making it easier for organisations to provide services to people in the EU.

body: What is wrong with the privacy notice shown here?
title: Privacy notices

_items.text: Confusing title and text in first paragraph
Unclear what the data usage policy is
Not clear who personal information will be shared with

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

This is an example of a particularly bad privacy notice. There is a mix of confusing language, incorrect terminology and misleading information. Additionally the signature box is in the incorrect place. On top of everything outlined here, under the GDPR you must allow an electronic request for access to the data, and fulfil this with an electronic copy of the data, unless otherwise requested.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

This is an example of a particularly bad privacy notice. There is a mix of confusing language, incorrect terminology and misleading information. Additionally the signature box is in the incorrect place. On top of everything outlined here, under the GDPR you must allow an electronic request for access to the data, and fulfil this with an electronic copy of the data, unless otherwise requested.

body: A number of our principals fall under the GDPR data lifecycle. Click on each pin to find out how.
title: Component title

_items.title: Create
_items.body:
Will the data be used to help deliver a service?

Will the data be linked with other information about the person?

Will the data be shared with other organisations or be used for research purposes?

Click to find out more under our following principal:

'Organisations should be open with people about what personal data they are collecting'

_items.title: Store
_items.body:
How is personal data secured to the extent that is possible without increasing the risk of security breaches?

Click here to find out more about our fourth principal 4 'Organisations should be open with people about the way personal data is secured'

_items.title: Archive
_items.body: How long do I need to keep this data for?

_items.title: Share
_items.body:
What data is being shared, with whom; for what purpose; under what conditions; and for what return (eg financial return, or because it’s a necessary part of providing a person with a service)?

Click here to find out more about our third principal 'Organisations should be open with people about the way personal data is shared

_items.title: Use
_items.body:
How will the organisation use different types of data? Will it be used to deliver a service, conduct analysis or simply maintain records?

Click here to find out more about our second principal 'Organisations should be open with people about how they use personal data' and here for our seventh principal 'Organisations should help people understand and influence how their data is collected and used'

_items.title: Destroy
_items.body:
How long am I allowed to keep this data?

How can I ensure it is destroyed securely?
